subject: Re: [junit] JUnit 4 with bea 9.2 workshop
msgSnippet: ... I ll be honest--I think I have internal definitions of what class and suite are that are preventing me from grasping what is probably an excellent
messageBody:
J. B. Rainsberger wrote:
> David Saff wrote:
>
>
>> Cédric Beust ♔ wrote:
>> > On 8/11/06, David Saff <saff@... <mailto:saff%40mit.edu>> wrote:
>> >
>> > There are indeed several ways to achieve this with JUnit, but why not
>> simply
>> > add @BeforeSuite and @AfterSuite? The intent would be much clearer,
>> > wouldn't it?
>> >
>>
>> Maybe. What do people think? For me, @BeforeClass and @AfterClass
>> already mean "before everything coming from _this_ class", and "after
>> everything coming from _this_ class", whether that's all the methods on
>> a test class, or all the classes referenced from a Suite class. This
>> means that @BeforeClass has a consistent meaning on both suite classes
>> and test classes. If suite classes have BeforeSuite, and test classes
>> have BeforeClass, then what does BeforeClass mean on a suite class? What
>> does BeforeSuite mean on a test class? It seems that fewer concepts is
>> better.
>>
>> Thoughts from frequent JUnit users?
>>
>
> Would it completely suck to implement this as @BeforeSuite, rather than
> @BeforeClass, and let @BeforeClass be an alias for @BeforeSuite? This
> way, people will tend to use @BeforeClass with the default suite (all
> tests in this class).
>
> Perhaps the Suite concept in JUnit 4 deserves to figure more prominently.
>

I'll be honest--I think I have internal definitions of what "class" and
"suite" are that are preventing me from grasping what is probably an
excellent suggestion. Could you write up some code examples? Thanks,

David
